page.name: References and Resources
page.content:
References and Resources

Andrade, H.G. (2014). Understanding Rubrics. Retrieved from http://www.saddleback.edu/uploads/goe/understanding_rubrics_by_heidi_goodrich_andrade.pdf

Bloom’s Taxonomy Action Verbs. (n.d.). Retrieved from http://www.paffa.state.pa.us/PAAE/Curriculum%20Files/7.%20DOK%20Compared%20with%20Blooms%20Taxonomy.pdf

Brualdi, A. (1998). Implementing performance assessment in the classroom. Retrieved from http://searcheric.org/digests/ed423312.html

Center for Applied Special Technology (CAST). (2010, January 6). UDL at a glance [Video file]. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bDvKnY0g6e4?forcedownload=1

Differentiated Instruction: Levels of Challenge. (2013). Boston, MA: World Education, Inc.

Dodge, J. (2009). 25 quick formative assessments for a differentiated classroom. New York, NY: Scholastic, Inc.

Education Oasis. (2011). Learning objectives: Stems and samples. Retrieved from http://www.educationoasis.com/instruction/bt/learning_objectives.htm

Fischer, M.W. (2005). Readiness Differentiation: Daring to Get Back on My Bike. Education World. Retrieved from http://www.educationworld.com/a_curr/voice/voice143.shtml

Fisher, D., & Frey, N. (2007).Checking for understanding: Formative assessment techniques for your classroom. Alexandria, VA: Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development.

Gee, J.P. (2007). What video games have to teach us about learning and literacy. New York, NY: Palagrave Macmillan.

Hall, T. (2002). Differentiated instruction. Wakefield, MA: National Center on Accessing the General Curriculum. Retrieved from http://www.principals.in/uploads/pdf/Instructional_Strategie/DI_Marching.pdf

Halverson, E. (2012, April 20). The backwards design framework [Video file]. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cveylXCpUmw

Harriman, V. (2013). WGU Interview presentation: Differentiated Assessment [Video file]. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7uLEh8dNDE?forcedownload=1

Heubner, T. (2010). What research says about differentiated instruction. Educational Leadership, 67(5). Retrieved from http://www.ascd.org/publications/educational-leadership/feb10/vol67/num05/Differentiated-Learning.aspx

Hollas, B. (2007). Differentiating instruction in a whole-group setting, 7-12. Peterborough, NH: Crystal Springs Books.

Kruse, K. (n.d.). How to write great learning objectives. Retrieved from http://www.kin.sjsu.edu/faculty/susanwilkinson/Content/179/11%20How%20to%20write%20Great%20Learning.pdf

Marks, K. (2013, October 1). Assessment in the Differentiated Classroom [Video file]. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Jw_ORNpcvQ

McTighe, J. (n.d.). Determining if Students have Developed Understanding [Video file]. Retrieved from http://www.differentiationcentral.com/videos2.html#assessment

 McTighe, J., & Thomas, R.S. (2003). Backward design for forward action. Educational Leadership. 60(5), 52-55. Retrieved from http://jaymctighe.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Backward-Design-for-Forward-Action.pdf

Miller, A. (2012). Six strategies for differentiation in project-based learning. Retrieved from http://www.edutopia.org/blog/differentiated-instruction-strategies-pbl-andrew-miller

National Research Council. (2012). Principles of learning for instructional design. In National Research Council, Improving adult literacy instruction (pp. 106-129). Retrieved from http://www.nap.edu/catalog/13242/improving-adult-literacy-instruction-options-for-practice-and-research

Northern Illinois University, Faculty Development and Instructional Design Center. (n.d.). Formative and Summative Assessment. DeKalb, IL: Author. Retrieved from https://www.azwestern.edu/academic_services/instruction/assessment/resources/downloads/formative%20and_summative_assessment.pdf

Pappano, L. (2011). Differentiated instruction reexamined. Harvard Education Letter, 27(3). Retrieved from  http://hepg.org/hel-home/issues/27_3/helarticle/differentiated-instruction-reexamined_499

Popham, J. (2008). Transformative assessment. Alexandria, VA: Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development.

Rubenstein, G. (2010). Ten tips for personalized learning via technology. Retrieved from http://www.edutopia.org/stw-differentiated-instruction-ten-key-lessons

Saldana, C. (2005). Differentiating instruction for a multilevel class. Focus on Basics, 7, 17-18. Retrieved from http://www.ncsall.net/fileadmin/resources/fob/2005/fob_7c.pdf

Tomlinson, C.A. (1999). Mapping a route toward differentiated instruction. Educational Leadership, 57(1). Retrieved from http://www.ascd.org/ASCD/pdf/journals/ed_lead/el199909_tomlinson.pdf

Tomlinson, C.A. (1999, 2nd ed. 2014). The differentiated classroom: Responding to the needs of all learners. Alexandria, VA: Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development.

Tomlinson, C.A. (2001). How to differentiate instruction in mixed-ability classrooms (2nd ed). Alexandria, VA: Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development.

Tomlinson, C.A. (2005). Differentiation in practice: A resource guide for differentiating curriculum, grades 9-12. Alexandria, VA: Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development.

Tomlinson, C.A. (2012). Readiness on differentiated instructions [Video file]. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MMvCd5Xafag

Tomlinson, C.A. (n.d.). A common misconception teachers sometimes have –I already differentiate [Video file]. Retrieved from http://www.differentiationcentral.com/videos.html#miscon

Tomlinson, C.A. (n.d.). A rationale for DI in today’s schools [Video file]. Retrieved from http://www.differentiationcentral.com/videos.html#introduction

Tomlinson, C.A. (n.d.). Suggestions on how to begin differentiating instruction [Video file]. Retrieved from  http://www.differentiationcentral.com/videos.html?forcedownload=1

Tomlinson, C.A., & Sousa, D.A. (2011). Differentiation and the brain. Bloomington, IN: Solution Tree Press.

U.S. Department of Education, Office of Vocational and Adult Education. (2010). Teaching Excellence in Adult Literacy (TEAL). Teal Center Fact Sheet No. 2: Universal design for learning. Washington, DC: American Institutes for Research. Retrieved from http://lincs.ed.gov/sites/default/files/2_TEAL_UDL.pdf

U.S. Department of Education, Office of Vocational and Adult Education. (2010). Teaching Excellence in Adult Literacy (TEAL). TEAL Center Fact Sheet No. 5: Differentiated instruction. Washington, DC: American Institutes for Research. Retrieved from https://teal.ed.gov/tealguide/diffinstruct

U.S. Department of Education, Office of Vocational and Adult Education. (2010). Teaching Excellence in Adult Literacy (TEAL). TEAL Center Fact Sheet No. 8: Effective lesson planning. Washington, DC: American Institutes for Research. Retrieved from https://teal.ed.gov/sites/default/files/Fact-Sheets/8_TEAL_Lesson_Planning.pdf

U.S. Department of Education, Office of Vocational and Adult Education. (2010). Teaching Excellence in Adult Literacy (TEAL). TEAL Center Fact Sheet No. 9: Formative assessment. Washington, DC: American Institutes for Research. Retrieved from http://lincs.ed.gov/sites/default/files/9_TEAL_Formative_Assess.pdf

U.S. Department of Education, Office of Vocational and Adult Education. (2010). Universal Design for Learning Guide. Washington, DC: American Institutes for Research. Retrieved from https://teal.ed.gov/tealguide/udl

U.S. Department of Education, Office of Vocational and Adult Education. (2011). Just Write! Guide. Washington, DC: Author. http://lincs.ed.gov/sites/default/files/TEAL_JustWriteGuide.pdf

U.S. Department of Education, Office of Career, Technical, and Adult Education. (2014). TEAL Math Works! Guide. Washington, DC: American Institutes for Research. http://lincs.ed.gov/sites/default/files/Teal_Math_Works_Guide_508.pdf

Vygotsky, L.S. (1978). Mind in society: The development of higher psychological processes. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press.

Webb, N.L., et al. (2005). Depth of knowledge (DOK) levels. Madison, WI: Wisconsin Center of Education Research, University of Wisconsin-Madison. Retrieved from http://static.pdesas.org/content/documents/M1-Slide_19_DOK_Wheel_Slide.pdf

Wiggins, G. (1998). Educative assessment: Designing assessments to inform and improve student performance. San Francisco, CA: Jossey-Bass.

Wiggins, G., & McTighe, J. (1998). What is backward design? Alexandria, VA: Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development. Retrieved from https://www.fitnyc.edu/files/pdfs/Backward_design.pdf

Wiggins, G., & McTighe, J. (2005). Understanding by design (expanded 2nd ed.). Alexandria, VA: Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development.

Willis, J. (2011). How to plan lessons using the video game model. Retrieved from http://www.edutopia.org/blog/how-to-plan-instruction-video-game-model-judy-willis-md

Wright, J. (n.d.). Differentiation strategies: Readiness-based differentiation. [Web log post]. Retrieved from http://www.conversationpieceslearning.org/differentiation-strategies---readiness-based-differentiation.html

Wormeli, R. (2006). Fair isn’t always equal: Assessing and grading in the differentiated classroom. Portland, ME: Stenhouse Publishers.

Wormeli, R. (2007). Differentiation: From planning to practice, grades 6–12. Portland, ME: Stenhouse Publishers.
